Anything in the constitution of the United States to forbid that confinement, the connotation on liberty?

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: No Your Honor.
We look on that in terms of its magnitude of any deprivation as just far different from the magnitude of the deprivation we're talking about right here.
The courts have always looked suspiciously on physical confinement and that's what we're talking about right here.
That's the essence of mental health's treatment.
It is what distinguishes commitment in the mental hospital from, say, a group home.
It is the physical confinement feature that distinguishes --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, what if the parent decide that a military academy is the best place as many parents have for border lining courageable children?
And they placed him in a private military academy where they must keep rigid hours, they can't live the grounds, a whole series of restraints, what about that?

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: I can't imagine this Court holding that that was -- there was a need for a due process protections there.
For one thing, I would not find the presence of state action there.
And secondly, it's readily distinguishable from our case.
Here, we are talking about a situation where the parents have gone to the state and said, “We cannot handle the child.
State, you take the child and lock the child up in effect.”
That would not happen in the military school situation.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What's the difference between that and this -- your institution had a tuberculosis sanitarium where the state commits people everyday.
They used to when it was agreed.

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: If it was a situation involving a --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You didn't walk out either.

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: I would then argue there that any person was entitled to a hearing before they were placed there because we are talking about long term deprivation.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You mean in the mean time, you walked around spreading your germs.

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: Well, we have always --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Do you think a state is powerless to stop that?

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: We have always conceded the emergencies --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Do you -- Oh, I see.

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: That emergencies, that the hearing can occur afterwards, that the state's hand is not tied in the tuberculosis situation, certainly there could be a hearing afterwards.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I had thought that a good deal of your case depended upon evidence, the record of which contains a good deal, that because of the relative unreliability of psychiatry as contrasted with the more conventional forms of medical practice, a hearing was appropriate because of the consequent risk of incorrect decisions.
And that therefore, you would distinguish the tuberculosis situation on that basis.

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: Your Honor, that is a part of our argument.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, I thought it was.

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: I think that the more basic argument that we have is that when there is a deprivation of liberty as extreme as right here, that in traditionally, our courts have provided at least notice in a hearing to the person involved and that --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well then that would require I would suppose logically for you to contend that the constitution requires notice and hearing with respect to a leg amputation or admission to a tuberculosis sanitarium.

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: I -- I think I would concede the tuberculosis sanitarium but --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Concede?

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: That --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: What do you mean?

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: That it would probably require a hearing there.

We don't feel like in the leg amputation, that the elements involved that we have in this case, distinguishing it in terms of the family autonomy and breaking into the family autonomy, it would be present in the leg amputation situation whereas they are here.
The potential for conflict of interest, the request by the family itself that the child be taken out of the home.
We feel like that those are different for those reasons.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Cromartie, aren't you -- don't you have a lot of difficulty trying to distinguish on the basis of the magnitude of the deprivation.

I thought your case rested on the point Mr. Justice Stewart made earlier, that the common law presumption rest on the notion that there's a community of interest between the parent and the child where there would be in the tuberculosis case and the leg amputation, all the rest.

But your point as I understood here in your brief was in part that you can't be so sure there's a community of interest in the mental institution context when the parent is asking that the child be placed in the home because it may will be a family conflict that -- is the source of the problem.
So, isn't the scope of your argument limited to the case in which the basis for the common law presumption is no longer applicable?

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: Your Honor, there were several points that we made.
That was one of them.
The other one was that this situation was different because the parent had gone to the state and asked the state to intervene.
And in the Wyman versus James sense, had ceded some of its authority that it traditionally would have to the state.
But also our argument was because of the manifest potential for conflicts of interest.
Just by nature, this is a stressful situation, emotional situation.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And that point really doesn't apply to any of these other hypothetical examples as I understand it.

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: It might will not Your Honor.
It might will not.
I was more troubled by the tuberculosis situation because of the stigma and that sort of thing involved in that situation than I was with the amputation situation.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Would you think it possible Mr. Cromartie that a child that is someone under 18 might be so emotionally disordered, disturbed, that they couldn't participate, they couldn't contribute anything in the same sense that some defendants in criminal cases are determined to be not competent to assist in their own defense.
Now, is that possible that that kind of a situation could arise with a seriously disturbed child, age 16 or 15?

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: I think it would be very rare.
The evidence shows that most of the children are mildly diagnosed here.
They are not the severely mentally ill.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, there can be psychotics at age of 16, can't there?

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: There can be.
The evidence is --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Psychopaths?

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: That it's not as frequent with children in adolescence is (Voice Overlap).

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, let's assume for a minute that you have the very seriously disturbed psychotic psychopathic person, you're going to have to have first a preliminary hearing to determine whether they are competent to assist and take part in a hearing?

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: Well, Your Honor in Jackson versus Indiana, you had a person who by all evidence was incapable of participating in that proceeding.
And yet the court felt it was important to provide procedural protections to that person.
The code of professional responsibility speaks to that also.
Canon 7 says that an attorney's responsibility is to do everything that he or she can to adequately get input from the client, into the client's wishes.
But there may be circumstances where the client is not able to participate.
And in that case, the attorney still has the obligation to fully represent that person.

Getting on toward the end of my argument, we feel that the cases of J.L. and J.R. very dramatically illustrate how some sort of hearing process, informal though it may be could have prevented both of them from spending over five years of their lives in a mental institution.
In the case of J.L., his primary outpatient therapist had recommended only a month or so before that he not be institutionalized.
And yet Janet Scott's recommendation was not even considered when J.L. was placed into that mental institution.
Of course also the evident shows that J.L. was placed in the institution, the decision was made three days before he ever showed up at the institution.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I -- I assume that I agree with what you say.
What's going to happen if we end up with the hearing with three psychiatrists on one side and three on the other, then what does the court do?

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: Somebody is going to have to make a decision.
I mean that -- that is -- that is typical --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Have you ever tried to make one with three psychiatrists on one side and three on the other?

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: If you haven't tried it, you'd be committed?

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: I made a many a time to this county attorney when I sat in and was one of the three members of an interdisciplinary team that sat and listened to evidence such as that.
I mean it's the same role that any judge performs in any trial where you have to weigh the different evidences presented to you and make a decision based on that.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Cromartie -- excuse me go ahead.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Oh, -- what are -- what is the issue of fact that would be determined in the hearing that the District Court is ordered be had?

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: Mental illness is grounded basically in behavior and there are lost of issues of fact as to what the person has done that allegedly gives rise to the conclusion of mental illness.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That's the ultimate issue in fact.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Is the --

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: The ultimate issue that the finder of fact would have to pass on is whether or not the child is or is not mentally ill?

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: With expert testimony, yes.
And secondly, there is the important.
And this may well be the most important issue in these cases.
And that is, should the child be here or should the child be somewhere else.
And right now, when you have a physician or someone else at an institution making that decision, they have really only two choices.
They can either say, “Child, go home.
We can't treat you at all.”
Or we're going to put you in this institution.”

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Oh, what type of person makes this decision?
Is it a psychiatrist?

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: I conceded in the last oral argument that the question of who was not so important as the question of how.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: It could be a layperson.

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: It could be, I mean I would not recommend that but I think it could be.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What would you recommend?

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: I would -- I think that the best and what is done in the new act is that the juvenile court judge would make the decision.
But now --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But if --

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: That's a matter for the legislature, it seems to me.
And it is not an issue that we have addressed nor that we have taken a position on.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Could I just make sure in Georgia now, if the state doctor determines that the child is mentally ill, does he also have to determine that he would benefit from the treatment?

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: Yes Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And does he also --

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: That frequently is not done.
And the record is very clear on that.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, would that be -- will that be an issue on remand under the District Court's remand?

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: Yes Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And does the doctor also have to find that there are some advantages to treating in the state institution rather than at home?

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: I think that that's implicit in that standard, yes.
That the treatment is appropriate in an institution as opposed to being in the home or in the foster home.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So you think under the present Georgia law, if the parent says, “Well, I know a lot but I just am -- I just can't handle them at home.
I agree with you that he could be treated at home but we just can't get along with them at home.”
Under the present Georgia law, the state must reject them?

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: Well, they may not but it's my position that they should.
But they frequently don't and the record is clear on that, that they frequently don't.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So, that the law permits them to take that kind of a child just because -- although he could be treated at home, the parents just don't want to treat him at home.

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I mean that's my construction of the law that it does not allow that.
Now, obviously, that is not shared by the psychiatrist.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Could -- could they not put him in a foster home?

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: Could the parents not placed them in the foster home?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: No, no, the state.
If they thought something less than institutional care was indicated.

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, yes, they could.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Cromartie, would a new statute require a finding that the two now would benefit from treatment?

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: An affirmant of finding.

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You said an answer to Justice White's question that the present Georgia law does not allow an institution to receive a patient if -- it finds, if the psychiatrist finds that he could be treated at home, is that right?

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: That's my construction, that if a child could be treated in the home and could -- would not be appropriately treated in the institution then they cannot accept that child.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yeah, but suppose he could be appropriately treated in the institution in the sense that you can now administer the treatment there.

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: Oh, okay.
If that's the question, then no, I don't think that the law requires that he'd be in the home rather than in the institution.
I'm sorry.
That --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So, if the parent comes to the state and say, “Well, I know we could treat them at home but I know I think and my doctors says, he could be treated in the institution also.
That the state may take him.”

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: The -- under the present law, yes they could.
If they can be approved --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: How about under the new law?

turn.speaker: john_l_cromartie_jr
turn.label: Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr.
turn.text: It's my construction of the new law that it would not be appropriate there.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you gentleman.
The case is submitted.
